metadata.case_name: Defendants v. Mutawalli of Dargah Hazarat Habbeeb Ali Shah Saheb & Board of Muslim Endowments

facts.text: The property known as Sama Khana and five tiled rooms inside the company pound of Dargah Hazarat Habbeeb Ali Shah Saheb at Katalamandi, Hyderabad belongs to the Dargah (wakf property).

Dargah was dispossessed of the property by the defendants on or about September 20, 1937, when defendants filed objections in proceedings for enrolment of the property as endowed property under Hyderabad Endowment Regulations.
Under Hyderabad Limitation Act II of 1322 F, Section 29c applied to suits relating to wakf, providing no limitation for suit for recovery of wakf property.
Part B States Laws Act 1951 came into force on April 1, 1951, extending Indian Limitation Act 1908 to Hyderabad and repealing corresponding Hyderabad law.
Suit for recovery of possession instituted on February 3, 1956 by mutawalli of the dargah and Board of Muslim Endowments, Hyderabad.
Trial court dismissed suit as barred by limitation under Article 142 of Indian Limitation Act 1908.
Andhra Pradesh High Court in C.C.C Appeal No. 5 of 1960 by judgment dated December 12, 1962 held suit governed by Hyderabad Limitation Act, not barred, and decreed suit.
On August 13, 1941, defendants instituted suit for declaration of title and obtained injunction restraining enrolment as endowment.
May 18, 1942: Property enrolled in Book of Endowment.
May 21, 1942: Summary proceedings under s.14 Hyderabad Endowment Regulation started by Director, Ecclesiastical Department.
June 20, 1942: Defendants appealed to High Court, obtained interim injunction restraining eviction.
February 14, 1942: Addl. Chief Judge consigned records to record room, action after High Court disposal. (Note: Date appears erroneous in text, contextually post-1942 proceedings)
October 15, 1945: High Court allowed defendants' appeal, remanded suit.
August 28, 1948: Trial court dismissed defendants' suit.
September 21, 1955: Appeal from that decree dismissed.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit is governed by the Hyderabad Limitation Act (no limitation for wakf recovery) or Indian Limitation Act 1908 (Article 142, 12 years from dispossession), considering Part B States Laws Act 1951 s.30.
Whether the suit is by or on behalf of the State Government, attracting Article 149 of Indian Limitation Act 1908.
Applicability of Sections 14 and 15 of Indian Limitation Act 1908 for exclusion of time.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit governed by Hyderabad Limitation Act, no limitation; application of Indian Limitation Act would confiscate existing cause of action without reasonable time.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hyderabad Limitation Act s.29c; Part B States Laws Act 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit by Board of Muslim Endowments, agent of State Government, governed by Art.149.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Muslim Wakfs Act 1954 ss.9,15; Halsbury; Tamlin v. Hannaford; State Trading Corp v. CTO

petitioner_arguments.text: Mutawalli is agent of State; limitation starts on appointment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Jewun Doss v. Shah Kubeer-ood Deen

petitioner_arguments.text: Exclusion under s.15 for period of injunction in prior proceedings.
Exclusion under s.14 for period summary proceedings pending.

respondent_arguments.text: Suit barred by limitation under Art.142; s.30 of Part B States Laws Act provides 2 years from April 1, 1951, suit filed 1956.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Limitation Act Art.142; Part B States Laws Act s.30

respondent_arguments.text: Board of Wakfs not agent of State; independent statutory corporation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Muslim Wakfs Act ss.9,15,48,54,64; Religious Endowments Act 1863

respondent_arguments.text: Mutawalli not agent of State post-1863; limitation runs from dispossession.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Shaikh Laul Mahomed v. Lalla Brij Kishore; Behari Lal v. Muhammad Muttaki

court_reasoning.text: Part B States Laws Act s.30 provides 2 years from April 1, 1951 for suits where Indian LA prescribes shorter period than prior law; Hyderabad had no limitation (unlimited), Indian LA Art.142 has 12 years, so shorter, allowing 2 years grace.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.30 construed liberally; suit governed by Indian LA as in force at institution date.

court_reasoning.text: Board of Wakfs is statutory corporation, not agent of State; State has no concern with its property or liability.
Mutawalli not procurator of Government post Religious Endowments Act 1863; limitation from dispossession Sept 20, 1937.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No fresh starting point on appointment.

court_reasoning.text: No exclusion under s.15 as no injunction against suit institution; s.14 contention not raised below, not permitted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mixed question of fact and law, first time in SC.

holdings.text: Suit governed by Indian Limitation Act 1908 Art.142; barred as instituted more than 12 years after dispossession and beyond 2-year grace under Part B s.30.
Suit not by or on behalf of State Government; Art.149 inapplicable.
No exclusion of time under ss.14,15.

precedents_cited.relevance: Corporation may be agent of State

precedents_cited.case_name: State Trading Corporation of India Limited v. The Commercial Tax Officer
Jewun Doss Sahoo v. Shah Kubeer-ood Deen
precedents_cited.relevance: Mutawalli as procurator under old regulation

precedents_cited.case_name: Shaikh Laul Mahomed v. Lalla Brij Kishore
precedents_cited.relevance: Mutawalli not agent of Government post-1863

precedents_cited.case_name: Behari Lal Ors. v. Muhammad Muttaki
precedents_cited.relevance: Suit by mutawalli not on behalf of Government

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Limitation Act II of 1322 F
statutes_cited.relevance: No limitation for wakf recovery suits; repealed

statutes_cited.name: Part B States Laws Act 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended Indian Limitation Act; 2-year grace for shorter periods

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs suit; 12 years from dispossession; no exclusion

statutes_cited.name: Muslim Wakfs Act 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Board as corporate body with superintendence powers, not State agent

statutes_cited.name: Religious Endowments Act 1863
statutes_cited.relevance: Government divested of management of endowments

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Endowment Regulations
statutes_cited.relevance: Summary proceedings for recovery; not affecting limitation here

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court decree set aside; trial court decree dismissing suit restored as barred by limitation.

key_quotes.text: "Section 30 should be construed liberally considering that it is intended to alleviate hardship consequential on the introduction of a shorter period of limitation."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The law of limitation applicable to the suit is the law in force at the date of the institution of the suit."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The Board of Wakfs though subject to the control of the State Government, is a statutory corporation and is vested with statutory powers, functions and duties."
key_quotes.speaker: court
